contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person |name = Ian Mune |image = |birthname = '''Ian Barry Mune''' |birth_date = 1941 |birth_place = [[Auckland, New Zealand]] }} '''Ian Barry Mune''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 1941) is a [[New Zealand]] character actor and director. He co-wrote and starred in [[Roger Donaldson]]'s first film, ''[[Sleeping Dogs (1977 film)|Sleeping Dogs]]''. He also directed ''[[Came a Hot Friday]]'', which featured comedian [[Billy T. James]] as the Tainui Kid, and ''[[What Becomes of the Broken Hearted?]]'', the sequel to ''[[Once Were Warriors (film)|Once Were Warriors]]''. ''[[What Becomes of the Broken Hearted?]]'' won nine of its 13 [[New Zealand Film and TV Awards|New Zealand Film Award]] nominations in 1999. It remains Mune's biggest commercial success to date. One of his best-loved films is the 1991 'coming of age' drama ''The End of the Golden Weather'', a film version of [[Bruce Mason]]'s [[The End of the Golden Weather|play]], written by Mune and Mason. In 1994 Mune played [[Robert Muldoon|Sir Robert Muldoon]] in the made-for-television mini-series ''Fallout'', depicting the end of the [[Third National Government of New Zealand|Muldoon-led National Government]]. He directed the original episodes of the short-lived television series ''Letter to Blanchy'' by [[David McPhail]] and [[Jon Gadsby]], and has featured in numerous [[Television New Zealand|New Zealand television]] dramas. Mune was an 'additional second unit director', as well as playing the part of Bounder in the film adaptation of ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]''. He played [[Buster Keaton]] in the TV movie ''[[Lucy: The Lucille Ball Story]]''. In 2008 Mune directed a telefeature movie called ''Life's A Riot''. It featured Andrew Grainger, Dominic Jennings and [[Alison Bruce]]. Mune also had a cameo role as a judge when the actor cast as the judge did not show up. He was born in [[Auckland]], and educated at [[Wesley College, Auckland]].
